Dear Michelle Lynn Carlton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 6/23/2023. An exit conference was conducted with the agency on 7/7/2023 . Due to
the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 248-860-787 .
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the
following information before employment may occur:
Sub-Section-Description 1
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
Sub-Section-Description 2
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the
person usually resides
One of six new employee records reviewed showed the employee's iChat clearance
was completed after the employee’s 6/6/2023 date of hire. The clearance was
completed on 6/12/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
Sub-Section-Description 1
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.

One of six new employee records reviewed showed the employee's central registry
clearance was completed after the employee’s 6/6/2023 date of hire. The clearance
was completed on 6/12/2023.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
Sub-Section-Description 1
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period
In three of six foster home records reviewed the reevaluation did not show
documentation of interviews with all household members as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
Sub-Section-Description 1
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
Sub-Section-Description 2
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child's initial dental exam
due by 2/9/2023 was completed late on 3/23/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.

Two of five adoptive family records reviewed showed the respective family's
adoption assessment was not provided timely related to the adoption assessment’s
completion date.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.
FOM-801-3 Medical passport.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of an initial medical passport.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of a December 2022
medical passport; and the medical passport dated 1/13/2023 did not show
documentation of the child’s 12/2/2022 dental exam.
ADM 300 Adoption Assessment Addendum.
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum,
must be used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption
Assessment, on an annual basis if the child has not been
placed for adoption.
In one of six open child adoption records reviewed the child’s adoption assessment
addendum due by 4/28/2023 was completed late on 6/1/2023.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12327(6) Special evaluation:
• The agency was apprised its staff shall not mail/date the letter to a foster
parent apprising the foster parent that a copy of the special evaluation is
attached prior to the supervisor's approval of the special evaluation report.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
FOM 722-8D Treatment plan:
• The agency was advised including the date on the treatment plan that a birth
parent or caregiver refused to sign the treatment plan, or that the treatment
plan was mailed, may aid it in showing compliance to the policy.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two corrective action plan(CAP) during the inspection
period, which did not relate to maltreatment in care.
The first CAP related to the agency’s 2022 Interim inspection where it received
the following rule violations:
• R400.12212(1)(h) Personnel records.
• R400.1212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.1237 (5)(d) Special evaluation.
• R400.12405(5)(a)-(b) Change of placement.
• R400.12413 (1)(c) (i)Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12419 (1)(c) Initial service plans.
• R400.12604(1)(c) Orientation and application.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
• ADM 980 Closing summary.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-08 Case Services Plans-Overview, Types, and Timeframes-
Supervisory Approval.
• FOM 722-08 Treatment Plans- Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The agency made progress with this 2022 Interim CAP. The agency provided
various documents and showed proof of actions implemented per this CAP. This
proof included spreadsheets, developed checklists, samples of supervision
meeting logs and unit meetings reviewing or discussing the various items outlined
in the CAP, samples of licensing file reviews, and emails related to family team
meetings, and adoption closing summaries. The agency’s efforts resulted in a
reduction of rule violations; and they received three repeat violations.
The second corrective action plan related to special investigation 2023C0000136
initiated 1/10/2023. The complaint alleged: a lack of follow up and support to a
child’s foster parents related to the child’s negative and aggressive behavior; not
providing a clothing allowance to the foster parents for the child; and not
reimbursing the foster parents for a day care registration. The agency was found
in compliance with these allegations; they received a violation for
R400.12403(2)(d) related to policy and procedures for not adhering to its clothing
policy/procedures. The agency’s CAP included: a review of the agency’s
allowance procedures with foster care staff, creation of a 30-day/replacement
checklist being completed/ turned in to the supervisor, and therein the program
manager, who will monitor compliance monthly and document via supervisor
meetings. A review of a mandatory unit meeting and sign-in sheet for 5/19/2023
showed the stated clothing procedures were reviewed with staff. There have been
no replacements since the initiation of this CAP in May 2023, and at this point the
agency is in compliance with this CAP.

Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted an annual chief administrator’s report dated 6/19/2023.
The report was completed per the rule and the form's requirements.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual independent financial audit for September 2022
and 2021, as well as an annual budget. No concerns were observed.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Foster care, adoption and licensing staff were interviewed. No specific concerns
were reported.
This agency does not provide independent living services; no youths were
required to be interviewed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the agency's office was conducted, and no safety issues or concerns
were observed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert.
Concern:
No operable smoke detectors on each level of occupancy and or near all sleeping
areas. The smoke detector on the main floor was beeping during the visit. The
smoke detector in the hallway upstairs was missing.
Resolution
The agency purchased a combination smoke detector/carbon monoxide detector for
the caregiver on 4/30/23. The device was delivered to the caregiver’s home on
5/1/23. The worker verified that the caregiver replaced the batteries in her current
smoke detector. Pictures were provided showing the installed detectors.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
